steps.description: Game entry point. Introduces Pip and indicates city location. Corn chip choices.
content: You are a pigeon named Pip in your prime. How coo is that? You reckon it's pretty coo.
Yaaaaaaawn. What a beautiful day in the neighborhood.
The rising sun tries to shine through thick clouds, bringing the surrounding rivers and city buildings into focus.
Everything is steel gray and blue in the early morning light.
A corn chip rests conveniently by your feetsies...

substeps.text: Yes, a pigeon. Stunning royal blue and gray feathers. Orange feetsies.

steps.description: You ate your first corn chip.
content: Delicious chip carbs fill your feather bod. Your energy goes up by 10. Hmmm... 10 what exactly?
You're not sure, but 10 feels like the right number unit. Welp, time to fly around this town like no one's business.

choices.text: Fly to that bridge over yonder

steps.description: No chips!! Just coffee for breaky!!
content: Too good for a carb-heavy breakfast, eh? Just a coffee-and-go kind of bird.
You fly to the nearest cafe and take a BIG SIP from a half-full mug left on a patio table.
Full on caffeinated, you fly like a bird out of hell in several circles because you feel ALIVE
Let's put this perpetual birdmotion machine to work!

substeps.text: SIIIIIIIP. The lukewarm bev flows through you. It's the perfect ratio of cream to coffee. Now you are ready for action.

choices.text: FLY OVER TO A BRIDGE WITH INTENT

steps.description: You found the skate punk cats...
content: You fly towards the east river bank. A group of cat crust punks sit atop a big chunk of cement under a bridge, smoking cigarettes.
They smoke 100s, blowing surly plumes and wax poetic on grindcore and anarchy.
One the cats steps forward. He's both a crust punk AND challenging you to a skate off! A lethal combo. Do you..

substeps.text: Cooler than you. Wearing t-shirts featuring bands you’ve never heard of: Death by Plastic Monstertruck, Puddleslap, Figboy and the Newtons.

choices.text: ask if he's seen any good movies lately

steps.description: Pick your skate option to race Carl!
content: The cat sneers as he grooms his ear and flicks the end of a cheap cigarette at you, but graciously allows you to pick your method of shreddin'.
You think to yourself everything cats do is adorable no matter how hardcore they try to be.
Looking into his arsenal reveals three choices of handlebar-less transportation:

choices.text: the ripped denim tradition of a regular skateboard

steps.description: No skating, just chat with Carl. He gives you binary code paper
content: You befriend the cat and learn his name is Carl. He seems like a sensitive and insightful soul.
You learn Carl enjoys painting water colors of 1980's action film scenes. After a pleasant conversation involving comparisons of your best Terminator impressions, you bid farewell to your new friend.
Just before you leave, Carl slips you a piece of paper with a strange series of binary code on it, featuring a weird ink stamp at the bottom.
He says, "You're alright Pip, ya know that. A real Maverick. I'm sure we'll see each other again soon."
You say "Thanks, Goose" and take the slip paper.

substeps.text: Real classic movie lines like: "I'll be back" and "Chill out, dickwad."

steps.description: Win the race with a skateboard! Get a binary code paper!
content: Ah, yes. The traditional skateboard.
You could legitimately wear a Thrasher t-shirt, but they don't come in tiny bird sizes.
You skate with the valience of ten thousand Greek chariots and so does the crust punk, but ultimately you best him.
You do a kickflip to rub victory in his face a little, and he sadly offers you a slip of paper as a reward. Aw, he seems like a sensitive soul.
The paper has a cryptic series of binary code on it, with a strange ink stamp. Cryptic, but not encrypted... huh.

steps.description: Lost the race with a longboard. Get a binary code anyways!
content: Like your father before you, you are a true Cali brah in your salty pigeon heart.
With the grace of a 120 year old sea turtle you carve slow S's down the hill. In that moment you swear you are infinite - since it certainly takes you long enough to complete the race.
The crust punk easily beats you speed wise, but is moved to tears by your beautious display. He slips you a non-slippery slip of paper as a reward.
He seems like a sensitive soul. You notice the paper is covered in strange binary code with a uniquely designed ink stamp...

steps.description: Win the race with sweet blades brah!
content: With your tiny foot chariots, you blaze down the hill like hell and think to yourself: this feels like flying!
Cross-checking with your memories of actual flight, it is pretty similar.
It's a tie down to the milisecond. You're not sure why this crust punk went through all the trouble of setting up professional-level tech for a street match but you feel cool as a participant.
He hands you a slip of paper and says Excellent match, you've earned this. Brink was a really underrated Disney made-for-tv movie. and seems to genuinely mean it. A sensitive soul he is.
The paper is covered in a mysterious series of binary code...

choices.text: Actually fly and not rollerblade home

steps.description: Get home after your first day out n about
content: You fly home and let out a big sigh.
You lay down in your feather down bed and try to go to sleep, but that “take me home country roads” song is stuck in your head for no reason.
Musical stylings of John Denver aside, you play through the day's events in your mind... pausing to consider that mysterious binary code.
And have you seen that stamp design somewhere before...?

steps.description: Day 2 begins - you eat a corn chip & gotta decide where to go
content: Another day, another corn chip. You eat the corn chip and it is so delicious you want to start a relationchip with it.
Or rather, you want someone to share in this chip fortune with you in a real relationship kind of way. You could made chip puns together.
Yeah. That would be nice.
Your reverie is usurped by thoughts of the mysterious binary code acquired yesterday. You figure there's a few places that may provide a bit more insight..

choices.text: Go to the Cathedral of Learning

steps.description: you picked cathedral of learning & run into Ira there.
content: As a bird with a hungry mind, you enjoy living close to the Cathedral of Learning.
As you enter that tall tower of tutelage and head to a floor full of classrooms and books, you see a possum friend named Ira from art electives back at University.
She's sitting in a corner, reading a book titled "How to Get Your Shit Together" and you walk over to say hello.
After initial pleasantries you can tell something is up. She sighs after long sentences and you notice dark circles under her eyes that have nothing to do with post-grunge eyeliner.
Ira confesses she's mega bummed since her agency job isn't what she imagined and it's draining her of creativity and personal-life energy points.

substeps.text: Ira was cool for sure. She cracked the best jokes in still life illustration class. During nude drawing sessions, she called it the Art S'nude-io. Ha. Classic.
An award-winning firm that does projects for local upscale restaurants. The other designers at the firm are cheese mongers on the side. A prestigious hobby?

steps.description: You picked supercomputing center, but are distracted by restaurant choices - deli or hipster bistro?
content: Ah the Supercomputing Center. A center for all things super and computing. This binary code probably relates to these things, so you head on over.
On the way, you're distracted by the fanfare of a new restaurant opening up on the Northside next to the <span class="substep" data-substep="1">old deli</span.

However the new restaurant looks pretty swanky. A man dressed in suave hipster attire heralds people towards the entrance. Is he really waving his Premiumley Waxed beard at people? Is he offering free kombucha? Is that...a bowl of artisan corn chips???
Even though you ate a chip just fifteen minutes ago, you are tempted by more substantial sustinance...

substeps.text: That old deli rules. They put banana peppers on every sandwich. The old Deli Man there called customers either Dorothy or Donnie - no other options it seemed.

choices.text: Embrace change & try out the new restaurant

steps.description: Listen sincerely to Iras predicament then show her binary code paper
content: You listen sincerely to Ira's tale of agency churn & burn, spending long hours toiling for peanuts.
It makes you a bit sad in your core. Such a creative person, burnt out and flattened emotionally.
Maybe everyone has to put in those hell-grindy hours and get sad before bustin' out like a caterpillar turning into a butterfly.
You say, "Ira. That sucks major! You are a cool person with the righteousness and know-how to destroy a small-to-medium sized planet. Destroy it with the power of your art!"
Ira smiles and says, "Thanks Pip, means a lot. Why are you flying around these parts anyways?"

substeps.text: A metal butterfly destroying it’s Slayer chrysalis with double-bass drums resounding in the background.

choices.text: Tell her about the binary code paper

steps.description: You shared a relatable story to Ira & kinda made it about you then show her the binary code
content: You tell Ira a relatable story hoping to put her at ease to know the pain is shareable.
You can’t stop sharing tales of your own cubicle woes. Oh no, what are you doing?
The walls of your own sharing enclose around you like the walls of your old cubicle. A beige trap made of felt and some crappy metal. You picture Karen your old coworker peeping over the wall at you.
Finally, you look up and yell “Ira! Work is dumb but you aren’t. I have major respect for your art and your drive, girl. You can do this.”

Ira looks at you for a solid 4 seconds before laughing and says “You’re a weird bird Pip, but I can dig it. Sounds like we had the same cubicle. And same Karen. What are you doing around the Cathedral anyways?”

substeps.text: Flashback to KAREN! DANG IT she doesn’t even know how to use Microsoft Paint don’t MESS WITH ME KAREN I SWEAR.

choices.text: Sheepishly continue to share, this time about the binary code paper

steps.description: You picked classic deli & recieve a delicious sando
content: The deli door rings mellifluously. It triggers a Pavlovian reaction, and all you can think of is an italian sandwich on Mancini's bread. Extra banana peppers.
The Deli Man says, "Hey there Donnie, what'll it be?" and you inform him of your sandwich desires.
You acquire the best looking sandwich this world has yet known. And it is all yours.

choices.text: pack that pristine bread & meat stack for secret eating at a later time

steps.description: You picked hipster deli & waited a long time for food. Gotta pick from 2 boujee food options
content: You swoop down and sample an artisan corn chip. It has hints of rosemary, garlic, and nostalgia for a rustic time you were never a part of but it's nice to think so.
You are told there will be a 30 to 45 minute wait by the chic looking hostess and you comply without thought. This will be worth it.
Finally, blissfully, you are seated and get ready to order...

steps.description: You chose to eat the deli sando right NOW
content: No time like the present! You're so hungry you could eat a cliche. Instead, you consume the sandwich with the ferocity of a shark showing off for the shark week camera crew.
TODO: finish this step

steps.description: Ira cracks the binary code for you, no problem atall. Head to the rum warehouse
content: You recount the crust punk happenings and show Ira the curious piece of paper.
Ira takes the paper in her prehensile possum tail & studies it for a hot minute. “Hmm. Doesn’t say much other than rum warehouse,” she says thoughtfully.
On top of being a badass artist, apparently Ira is fluent in binary code. Dang.
You thank Ira for having such a cool brain and head out.

substeps.text: Fluent in binary code, really though? Maybe you'll ask her to hang sometime to see what other stuff is going on in her steel trap of a brain. But she’s probably too cool and connected and maybe you’ll ask later and anyways you’re super busy solving this weird puzzle and and and and and AND

steps.description: Flying to & finding the rum emporium
content: The Rum Warehouse is a blue cinder block building by a bridge and train tracks.
You fly in random circles until you see it & swoop in, tucking your wings close to your bod while making dramatic divebomb sound effects - NEeeeEEERRRRRRR PSHHHHHH!!
You land and sincerely hope no passersby heard your potentially embarassing beak-sounds, then pivot to ransack your bird brain for relevant info...
The warehouse owner is also the lead distiller. A no-nonsense type with a steely gaze and quiet disposition.
Word around town is he walked out on a cushy corporate job after a particularly boring meeting, and never looked back.

substeps.text: He thinks social media is a suck-up suckfest. Unsurprisngly, he doesn't prefer authority figures.

steps.description: You picked olive and cheese board
content: A variety of food choices presented on a board is the ideal way experience fine dining.
Soon enough an assortment of breads, olives, and cheeses are within your wingspan.
The meal is satisfying, yet not overfilling as you often feel after a typical deli experience.
Maybe you should branch out more. Olive branch out.

choices.text: Pay the steep tab (oof) & head towards the Supercomputing Center with fiery independant research intentions
Pay the steep tab (yikes) & ask that spicy scented bearded man if he knows anything about secret codes

steps.description: You ordered breakfast for dinner at the boujee hipster joint.
content: As an adult, truly no one can stop you from ordering breakfast for dinner.
A beautiful meal which consists of a venn diagram of both protein-packed options or sweet, sweet carbohydrate cakes.
The time of day doesn't confine you to the types of foods you consume! You are your own bird.
Being a boujee hipster bistro, the breakfast options consist of lebda, salmon, and lemon poppyseed.
The food transports you into a state of bliss that is only interuppted by the nagging feeling you have an unsolved mystery at wing.

substeps.text: The food IS delicious as it is expensive. Is this the natural progression of modern eating or is this a construct of gentrification AKA a more sinister manifestation of how the haves and have nots spend their time and money? Is a bistro just a bistro anymore?

choices.text: Pay the steep tab (oof) & head towards the Supercomputing Center with fiery independant research intentions
Pay the steep tab (yikes) & ask that spicy scented bearded man on the way out if he knows anything about secret codes

steps.description: Youve just entered the rum emporium
content: As you enter the rum emporium, you take in your surroundings - the length of which features a no-frills bar, behind which sits two pot-bellied copper distilleries.
A local-art style sign on the wall.
The owner himself, a surly gray dog in a plain white tee and gym shorts scratches behind his ear as he gets a bucket full of soapy water ready for mopping.
You take a seat and wonder what you could possibly ask in a casual way regarding binary codes on slips of paper.
A lively bartender appears...

substeps.text: The hand-painted sign says, "Venture Capitalists? More like Denture Crapitalists." Heh.

choices.text: oh-so-casually ask if the owner used to code
order a spicy bevvy & ask if they need someone to make them a website

steps.description: Leave the boujee bistro after breakfast for din && go to the Supercomputing Center
content: Your coin purse is considerably lighter, but your brain is fueled by nutrients aplenty.
The supercomputing center comes into view as you fly into the vicinity.
It's quittin time and some nerdy types slouch out of the building towards their Honda Civics.
You need to sneak into this bastion somehow to get ANSWERS.

choices.text: slouch with the best of them & pretend to be an employee who forgot a laptop charger

steps.description: Ask that bearded man about binary code after breakfast for din
content: "Hey there beardy-man.." you trawl while stepping out the bistro.
TODO

steps.description: You packed your sando & hit the road to the supercomputing center
content: You packed your sando & hit the road to the supercomputing center
TODO

steps.description: you ask the rum bartender if the distillery owner used to code
content: "So uhh.. did the owner used to plink around on the computer keys for a living?" you ask with the subterfuge of a penguin in the rainforest. The bartender side-eyes you.
"Yeah he did. Who's askin'?"
You avoid his scary side-eye and notice the same image from the paper carved into the wood of the bartop, with an anarchy symbol carved over top.
"...A fellow anarchist, that's who." You nod towards the carving.
The bartender guffaws. "Right, the owner Charlie is rather anti-authority. I'm more libertarian myself, but Charlie hates his old company so much he did that when we opened this place."
A company logo, then? You're certain you've seen it somewhere before the binary code paper...but where exactly.

The barkeep polishes a glass pensively. He remarks, "Yeah, he quit around the time of peak mech output. The MBOT-3000 had just been released. He was their top engineer and couldn't take anymore corporate bullshit. You know how it goes."
Aha! All those broken down police mechs rusting out under bridges and covered in leaves, garbage, and crappy graffiti. Company logo slapped on the sides, still visible under all the grime.

choices.text: tip that bartender way over 20% and head out

steps.description: you order a spicy bevvy & ask for computer work
content: "Hey there bar man. Shake me up one of those spicy tiki beverages. Extra spice, please," you order with machismo.
The barkeep grunts and slides down one glass of tiki torch.
You sip and hiccup a little flame. "So, does this fine establishment need an online presence? I know a guy that can code - it's me. I'm the guy."
You puff out your chest to show how qualified you are.
The barkeep gives you a stern side-eye which makes a little smoke escape your beak in nervousness.
"Eh, we're good on the website front. Charlie, the owner used to code back in the day and whipped us up a Screeact Site no problem."
He polishes a glass and ponders aloud, "Hey Charlie, I never get any days off. Need an extra barkeep?"
Charlie the owner grunts in approval as he mops the floor in back. "Well, you gotta job slinging spicy drinks if you want it," the barkeep says to you without missing a beat.
As you consider, you notice the same symbol from the sheet of paper carved into the bartop with an anarchy symbol overtop. Edgy, ineed.

choices.text: tip & dip out. you'll hold out for that rando high-paying freelance work

steps.description: tip that bartender well and head out
content: You fly home, and do what you do best: overanalyze the situation.
What the heck are these clues? Why do you even care? Do you have anything better to do? No? Why not???
You remember how popular those mechs were: a unit on every block keeping the peace.
Peaceful for whom was the question.
Everyone was cursing about the "robots takin over!" for a while. Initially they were simply an annoying fixture that doled out tickets and broke up lame street fights.
Then sometimes raided a home or two. Or more. Used a little more force than necessary.
Until that one day. That one day... a kid you went to grade school with decided to try and hotwire one.
You still remember sitting next to her in AI for Ethics class. Everyone called her by her web handle, Fl4ppyh4x, or just Fl4ppy for short.

You still remember when she got knocked down in gym class while playing sharks & minnows, and her mom picking her up to go get stitches. The whole class climbed the junglegym to wave goodbye as her mom's minivan pulled away.
She didn't deserve the end. She was too young. Too curious. Had too much success hacking into rent-a-scooters and reselling them online.
You shudder unexpectedly.
Maybe this is why you care. Maybe you should stop before it gets too dangerous.
You should stop before you remember too much...
Oof, no no no. No sir. You promised yourself convenient truths after it was already too much.
You try to memory dump scary brain thoughts and achieve sleep.
You hope to dream of a cotton candy nest.

steps.description: What a delicious house upgrade
content: You wake the following morning with too much on the brain, despite the memory dump.
You supposed brains aren't identical to computer RAM, so what else can get rid of these pesky memories...
A distraction of social sorts is in order! You have the day off, after all.
Well, every day is off these days. Freedom! But at what cost?
Lack of income aside, you ponder who to ping for hanging out purposes.

steps.description: skeptically accept the job
content: TODO: do you dream of your former life here?

steps.description: Ira, that sassy she-devil
content: You ping Ira on your contact-friend-machine and she pongs back.
She asks you if you'd like to come with her to a local art show in which she's featuring a few new paintings.
You ask her the theme or inspiration and she says , "lul u will c soon!"
You jazz yourself up for the event, happy for a memory-free distraction.
Arriving fashionably 7 minutes late to the gallery location, you meet up with Ira outside the venue, an old factory building by the river.

choices.text: sashay inside for an art experience

steps.description: Carl, the warm-hearted crust punk
content: You ping Carl on your contact-friend-machine and he pongs back.

steps.description: sashay inside for an art experience
